channel.title: NPR Morning Edition
channel.description: Morning Edition takes listeners around the country and the world with multi-faceted stories and commentaries every weekday. Hosts Steve Inskeep, Leila Fadel, Michel Martin and A Martínez bring you the latest breaking news and features to prepare you for the day.

item.title: Nothing lasts forever, except maybe the Goo Goo Dolls
item.description: The band's frontman, John Rzeznik, talks about their new EP, Summer Anthem, and how, as he approaches 60, he might consider taking guitar lessons.

item.title: FBI searches the home of former Trump adviser John Bolton
item.description: The FBI says its searches of Bolton's home and office was authorized by a court but declined to provide further details. Bolton is a frequent critic of the president.

item.title: Erik Menendez has been denied parole
item.description: California denied parole for Erik Menendez, who along with his brother Lyle have spent more than three decades behind bars for their parents' murders. Lyle Menendez faces a parole hearing on Friday.

item.title: Lawyer for some of Jeffrey Epstein's alleged victims discusses files release
item.description: The Justice Department is starting to share files on the late convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein with the House Oversight Committee. NPR talks with James Marsh, a lawyer for some of his accusers.

item.title: Famine confirmed in northern Gaza, says U.N.-backed panel
item.description: Famine has been officially declared in northern Gaza, a U.N.-backed group of experts warns — marking the first such confirmation in the Middle East.

item.title: Offered a cash price for a prenatal genetic test? It may be your best bet
item.description: An expectant mom got a $750 bill for a blood test to check for genetic abnormalities in her baby. Then she tried to figure out why it was so high.

item.title: First wave of Epstein files has been sent to Congress, says Oversight Committee chair
item.description: The Justice Department began delivering files from its Jeffrey Epstein investigation to the House Oversight Committee on Friday. The panel plans to release some of the files publicly.

item.title: Morning news brief
item.description: DOJ to give first batch of Jeffrey Epstein files to House Oversight Committee, California puts redistricting plan on November ballot to counter Texas, U.S. retailers raise prices on some items.

item.title: New Justice Department hire compared Jan. 6 prosecutions to the Holocaust
item.description: An NPR investigation finds that a new Justice Department hire compared the Jan. 6 riot prosecutions to the Holocaust, promoted conspiracy theories and called for defendants to receive reparations.

item.title: What happens when people stop trusting their government's economic data?
item.description: What happens when people stop trusting their government's economic data? Planet Money reports on what happened in Greece.
